item.title: Help is on the way (How and from Where?)
item.description:
I have put together a list of different types of help that are either already in Nepal or on the way. Please help me grow this list by sharing thoughts and links on comment section below.

Although, we cant be there to help, I hope together with our effort we can assure our families, that HELP is ON THE WAY.

I have categorized help (whether its monetary or not) based on their source (country, agencies).

Click here for list of agencies.

List of Countries that have stepped up to help.

Australia

  • Australia is sending in a Crisis Response Team and two humanitarian expert.
  • Australia has pledged $5 million distributed as follows:
    • $2.5 million to assist Australian non-government organisations;
    • $2 million to support United Nations partners; and
    • $0.5 million to support the Australian Red Cross.

My update on the situation in Nepal: http://t.co/5t7shKO6up

— Julie Bishop (@JulieBishopMP) April 26, 2015

Canada

  • Canada is contributing 5,000,000$ and also sending personnel help. link

We are deploying a Canadian Armed Forces Disaster Assistance Response (DART) assessment team to Nepal immediately, in response to the earthquake.

Posted by Jason Kenney on Saturday, April 25, 2015

China

  • China has sent 68-strong China International Search and Rescue Team (CISAR). The team will arrive in Kathmandu midday Sunday (April 26, 2015). See the press release here.

France

  • France is sending 11 rescuers and emergency equipment to Kathmandu on Sunday (April 26, 2015). link

Germany

  • Germany has sent a team of 52 relief workers that include doctors, search experts, rescue dogs. link

India

  • A tweet from Narendra Modi about donation of Rs. 51 lakh by Pujya Morari Bapu. Many thanks to him. As of yet I have not found details on how this money will be used in Nepal.

Received a call from Pujya Morari Bapu. He has donated Rs. 51 lakh for relief work in Nepal. My deepest gratitude to him.

— Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) April 25, 2015
  • Series of tweets from Vikas Swarup of Ministry of External Affairs, India regarding help being deployed to Nepal. A total of 285 NDRF team members have been sent to help with rescue along with 43 tons of relief material, including tents and food link.

285 NDRF team members have been flown in from India in 3 IAF aircrafrts to assist Nepal Army in rescue operations @MEAIndia #NepalEarthquake

— Embassy of India KTM (@eoiktmnp) April 25, 2015

Earlier today: relief materials and equipment for earthquake assistance being loaded on aircraft bound for Kathmandu pic.twitter.com/6hMyOkMrT6

— Vikas Swarup (@MEAIndia) April 25, 2015

Israel

  • Israel also plans to dispatch search and rescue teams and humanitarian aid to Nepal as per Times of Israel.

  • IsraAID also has setup a fund raising page to collect funds. Here is the link.

Italy

  • Italy has made $316,000 available through International Red Cross. See press release here.

Japan

  • Japan is sending around 70 members (on Sunday April 26, 2015) from the National Police Agency, the Fire and Disaster Management Agency and the Japan Coast Guard who will coordinate relief efforts with the Nepalese government.link

Malaysia

  • Malaysia will send 20 medical doctors along with a 30-man rescue team and medicines and medical supplies.link

New Zealand

  • 45 specialised urban search and rescue (USAR) personnel from New Zealand have been sent to Nepal. The crew also includes four dog handlers and are trained in using search and rescue cameras, listening devices and line rescues. link

Pakistan

  • Pakistan is sending in rescue teams, more equipments to help rescue teams, hospital beds, Doctors, and food items.

Urban search&rescue team of Pak Army equipped with ground penetrating radars,concrete cutters,sniffing dogs &eqpt sent 2 help rescue teams-2

— AsimBajwaISPR (@AsimBajwaISPR) April 26, 2015

To provide relief to EQ victims in Nepal,4 C-130 acs with 30 bedded hosp,Army Drs,special search&rescue teams, food items left 4 Nepal-1/2

— AsimBajwaISPR (@AsimBajwaISPR) April 26, 2015

Poland

  • Poland has sent 81 firefighters of the State Fire Service, 12 search and rescue dogs and 6 doctors of Polish Center for International Aid. link

Russia

  • Russia is getting ready to send more than 50 rescue workers with extensive experience in rescue missions. link

Singapore

  • Sigapore is preparing to send a 55 man search and rescue team in addition to $100,000 contribution towards Singapore Red Cross. See press release here.

South Korea

  • South Korea has pledged 1M$. link.

Sri Lanka

  • An airforce plane carrying four doctors will leave for Nepal on April 26th. Srilankan government will also send dry ration and other essential items by tomorrow (April 27th). link

Scandinavian countries (Norway, Sweden, and Denmark)

  • Scandinavian country will allocate $3.8 million for aid which will be distributed through United Nations and Charitable organizations. See press release here.

United Kingdom

  • UK has sent a team of “eight-strong” team that consist of experts in search and rescue. See press release here.

United States

  • A press release from USAID promising “an initial $1 million in emergency assistance” through Government of Nepal along with disaster response team.link

The U.S. Government has been providing ongoing disaster preparedness support – and #WeStandWithNepal ready to help....

Posted by U.S. Embassy Kathmandu, Nepal on Sunday, April 26, 2015

List of agencies that have stepped up to help

United Nation

  • UNICEF has also setup a page for donation.

American Red Cross

  • The American Red Cross is committing an initial $300,000 to Nepal red cross. See press release here.

GlobalLiving

  • GlobalLiving has started a page to raise funds (target $1,000,000). So far $198,000 has been raised (as of 10:42PM EST April 25, 2015). See their page here.

AmeriCares

  • An emergency response team from the AmeriCares India office in Mumbai is headed to the impact zone and relief workers are preparing shipments of medical aid and relief supplies for survivors. See this link to donate and for announcement.

item.title: Setting up octopress
item.description:
I have had a pretty great workflow for using octopress that involved hosting my website in Amazon AWS using ponyhost. However, Amazon started charging me so i decided to move my site to github pages (something i wanted to do anyways). I could have just used my old octopress folder and pushed the repo to github, but i decided to setup everything from scratch so that i could write this post.

Also, octopress has an excellent step by step guide to setting up your octopress blog and deploy it to your favorite host. The following steps are roughly based on what i did after following the instruction from octopress.org.

Few programs that is required before setting up octopress are:

  • Git
  • Ruby

Installation

The first step is to clone octopress repo into a folder. I named mine mshakya.

bash $ git clone git://github.com/imathis/octopress.git mshakya $ cd mshakya

The folder mshakya has following files:

bash ├── CHANGELOG.markdown ├── Gemfile ├── README.markdown ├── Rakefile ├── _config.yml ├── config.rb ├── config.ru └── plugins

Install other dependencies that are required for octopress using bundle - a ruby dependency management tool - based on dependencies listed in Gemfile - A format for describing gem dependencies for Ruby programs - using bundle:

bash $ bundle install

Then, install the default octopress theme using rake (ruby make).

bash $ rake install

which will add three new folders

bash ├── Gemfile.lock ├── public ├── sass └── source

sass stands for Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets. It contains files for customizing octopress theme.

public: contains html files for the website (this folder is filled when the website is generated, more on this later).

source: contains folders and files from which the blog will be generated.

├── _includes
├── _layouts
├── _posts
├── assets
├── atom.xml
├── blog
├── favicon.png
├── images
├── index.html
├── javascripts
└── robots.txt

Configuration

Configuration can be setup in _config.yml. You can setup your twitter, github, facebook, etc. accounts to your blog here.

Post

Octopress has a recipe in its rakefile to create a new blog post. Just type: $ rake new_post["Title of the post"] This will generate a file with Jekyll naming convention YYYY-MM-DD-post-title.markdown with following header or yaml front matter in the folder source/_posts:

YAML --- layout: post title: "Setting up octopress" date: 2014-11-09 18:55:49 -0500 comments: true categories: [octopress, technical] ---

Generate the blog by:

bash $ rake generate

Preview the cite locally using:

bash $ rake preview The cite will be available at localhost:4000

Deploy to github pages

First step is to create a github repo at github.com following the instructions here. One requirement is that the repo name should be in the format username.github.io where username is your user name in github.

Then, setup your local folder to deploy it to gihub repo that we just setup using:

bash $ rake setup_github_pages

This will ask for the Repository url and password. As a result, it will rename the remote pointing to imathis/octopress from origin to octopress, add the github page as the origin remote, change the branch from master to source, * Configure your blog’s url according to your repository*, and creates a directory _deploy with all the files ready to be deployed to github repo as master branch.

So,

bash $ git remote -v should show two remotes:

bash octopress git://github.com/imathis/octopress.git (fetch) octopress git://github.com/imathis/octopress.git (push) origin: https://github.com/username/username.github.io.git (fetch) origin: https://github.com/username/username.github.io.git (push)

and, its branch should be source:

bash $ git branch * source

Additionally, folder _deploy has only one remote and is on branch source.

``` bash $ cd _deploy $ git remote -v

origin git@github.com:mshakya/mshakya.github.io.git (fetch) origin git@github.com:mshakya/mshakya.github.io.git (push)

$ git branch * master ```

The folder structure in main folder mshakya now look like this:

├── CHANGELOG.markdown
├── Gemfile
├── Gemfile.lock
├── README.markdown
├── Rakefile
├── _config.yml
├── _deploy
├── config.rb
├── config.ru
├── plugins
├── public
├── sass
└── source

Steps to update the blog

1. cd into the folder

bash cd mshakya ####2. create a new post

bash $ rake new_post["Title of the post"] ####3. Write the blog The new post file (markdown) is located in source/_posts/. Preview the website at localhost:4000 using

bash $ rake preview ####4.Generate the website bash $ rake generate

5. Deploy the website to github using

bash $ rake deploy

This will push the website to master branch of your github repo. The website should be updated and available to view at username.github.io

6. Push the infrastructure octopress file changes to github

Commit the changes in the octopress infrastructure files and commit changes to source branch of github repo. For example, after making changes in _config.yml

bash $ git stage _config.yml $ git commit -m "personalized config file" $ git push origin source An important thing to note that the website (username.github.io) will show files in the master branch only.

Steps to stop redirecting the domain

I did not update my domain name (microbeatic.com), so I had to stop forwarding mshakya.github.io to microbeatic.com. Here is what I did.

1. edit CNAME

  • I changed the microbeatic.com in CNAME file (located in source/).

2. rake it all

  • Then, I did the usual:

bash $ rake generate $ rake deploy

References:

  • octopress.org
  • miguelcamba.com

item.title: Teaching Statement
item.description:
I am attending a two day workshop in Teaching statements. Here i would like to lay down some of the points that i wrote down during group discussion session with other attendees, who are also interested in applying for an academic position that involves teaching. Additionally, many faculty positions now require a teaching statement. I think this post will help me to form my own teaching statement and philosophy as well. All my posts are written with no proof reading and corrections, so they could be filled with grammatical and spelling mistakes, and sometimes even unorganized thoughts. So, bear with me.

Here are some of the points that were shared by all participants.

In a teching statement:

  • clearly articulate your passion and motivation for teaching.
  • communicate your ideas about teaching effectively through a clear write up.
  • show your teaching experience, if you have any.
  • show that you are familiar with new teaching technologies.
  • discuss your teaching plans and strategies that you plan to implement in that institution.
  • write about how your teaching style and philosophy fits with that of the institution you are applying to.
  • go through some classes offered at the institution and talk about how you can fill some of the gaps in the classes offered at the institution.
  • demostrate your enthusiasm for teaching.
  • state a philosophy that everyone can be a teacher and a learner too.
  • talk about teaching in different situations.
  • list out previous mentoring experiences, for example, mentoring graduate and undergraduate students.
  • demonstrate how you have embraced new teaching technologies.
  • show your vision in curriculum development as well.
  • show how you can incorporate research and experience for students.
  • show evidence of resilience measurement.
  • show maturity.
  • try to avoid jargons in the statement and give specific examples of teaching.
  • do not dish out other teaching approaches even though you do not agree with it.
  • talk about your pedagogical approach.
  • take in consideration the potential class sizes.
  • it should be very different from your CV.
  • make the statement personal as it can be used as a way to gaze your overall personality.
  • think about type of teacher you want to be.
  • the statement should focus on not what you teach, but how you teach.

item.title: Column conservation scores
item.description:
What i am looking for is infact not conservation score, its an exactly the way profiles are scored or the way PSSMs are score. I am much more interested in how each amino acid are scored in a column of the alignment, and not in the score that represents the whole column. My kind of score should put heavy emphasis on the amino acid that are highly conserved and low emphasis on the columns that are equally present, but not highly conserved.

I have come across many conservation scores that score the column conservation of an alignment. There are many different types of it. Here i describe them sequentially based on either original papers or the reviews. I also try to be explicit in describing only scores that measures the column conservation and not the score of the whole sequence. A publication by William S.J Valdar sounds the most suited one in terms of describing the categorizing the scores. It is important for me to find out how not the whole column or sequence is scored, but instead whats the score of each amino acid based on its presence, absence, and frequency, for i will be using this information to then compare it to the corresponding multiple sequence alignment and then inferring how different similar or they are. Here he categorizes the scores as:

  • Symbol Frequency Scores
  • Symbol Entropy Scores
  • Stereochemical Property Scores
  • Mutation Data Scores
  • Stereochemically Sensitive Entropy Scores
  • Weighted Scores

Henikoff weighing

I have recently tried to understand this weighing system in more details as this is the one that is used in profile construction and also in PSSM construction. Although Wang et al tries to explain the method like this :

How does it score amino acid residues in an alignment column?

In this method, first, equal share of weight is assigned to each residue. For example, if an alignment column consist of two different amino acid types, M and K, then each residue is assigned equal weight of 0.5 and 0.5, regardless of its distribution.

Here, if a column is conserved it is inversely proportional to number of sequence.

An example alignment:

GYVGS
GFDGF
GYDGF
GYQGG

Here, G in the first and fourth column is scored as = 0.25 Y in the second column is scored as = 0.17 F in the second column is scored as = 0.5

An example 2:

A score for all amino acids given using Henikoff protein profile, including gap, calcualted using prophecy script in EMBOSS

2.00 0.00 -1.25 3.75 5.00 -3.25 2.75 1.38 -0.75 0.00 1.75 -1.50 -0.88 2.38 0.00 1.50 3.12 0.50 2.62 2.62 0.00 -0.62 -3.75 0.00 -2.88 0.00 0.05 0.05

based on this column of the alignment

TEQQSST--------

highlighting the amino acid scores in the profile represented from the amino acid

2.00 0.00 -1.25 3.75 **5.00** -3.25 2.75 1.38 -0.75 0.00 1.75 -1.50 -0.88 2.38 0.00 1.50 **3.12** 0.50 **2.62** **2.62** 0.00 -0.62 -3.75 0.00 -2.88 0.00 0.05 0.05

I am not clear on how the scores for other amino acid that are not in this columns are calculated. Additionally, although gap makes up more than 50% of the column, it only accounts for 0.5

What are some advantages?

Its very fast and simple, and already implemented in the EMBOSS prophecy program. It is independent of how the sequence are ordered and it uses all the information.

What are some disdvantages?

Problem with closely related sequences in the alignment. It has equal valuation for all sequences, even if its duplicate.

What are some conditions where it can be implemented?

“In Henikoff weighting, for an amino acid at position of sequence , we first determine the subset of sequences that also have an amino acid in the same column of the multiple alignment. Each sequence in this subset may begin and end in different columns of the multiple alignment. We find the first column in which all of these sequences in the subset are represented either with an amino acid or an internal gap (i.e., excluding N- and C-terminal gaps). We call this . Similarly, we identify the last column of this subset in which all of these sequences are represented either with an amino acid or an internal gap. We call this . The weight of the amino acid at position of sequence is then [see below] where is the number of different amino acids at alignment position j but considering only those sequences in the subset, and is the total number of the same amino acid i type as the residue of sequence i in alignment column j in the subset.”

Here, the authors explains how the henikoff score is calculated. There are some important point to be noted here, the position is the position at an unaligned sequence and is not used anywhere in the formula, so its rather not important to understand the concept. Then, from the multiple sequence alignment, a subset of sequences are picked based on the presence of an amino acid - here, it is rather confusing on what they are trying to explain - are the subset based on the presence of same amino acid in the column or its random selection -, the former seems to make more sense, but as you go further, the is the number of different types of amino acids in the subset, so if former were true, then it will be 1 throughout. Among the subset, the first aligned column from both ends are identified and recorded as and . After these naming conventions are used in the formula stated above, but its unclear to me whats its value. At first glance, i thought it was a naming convention of the column.

The reason that the method was developed was to minimize the complexity introduced by the tree based methods.

“A simple method to represent the diversity at a position is to award each different residue an equal share of weight, and then to divide that weight equally among the sequences sharing the same residue. So, if in a position of a multiple alignment, different residues are represented, a residue represented in only one sequence sequence contributes a score of to that sequence, wheas a residue represented in sequence contributes a score of .

Position based weights are simply generalizations of correct weights from single positions to whole sequences by summation overal all positions “

PSIC

item.title: Handy unix commands
item.description:
• Search for a string within files

      `grep 'string' *.*`

search all files for the specified string

  • Search and replace strings in files with same extension

find . -name '*.txt' -exec sed -i 's/old/new/g' '{}' \;

finds all *.txt files in the current folder and replaces old with new throughout the files

  • Adds / to folder

    ls -F

item.title: Weekend roundup
item.description:
• Guides on using make for reproducible data analysis can be found here, here, and here.
  • Sqlite in a nutshell
  • Good advices here for all levels from undergraduate, graduate, to postdocs.
  • Another way to collaborate in a real time for a paper or anything else can be found here
  • Many interesting article here in n-category cafe.
  • Alfred Russel Wallace gets a statue, finally.
  • More readings on neutral evolution here.
  • The other side: How do the candidates get evaluated can be found here.
  • Walla, time for Rscripts.
  • More experimental evolutions here
  • vimdiff to find the difference between two files. Find it here
  • This guy hates GIT and has 10 reasons for it here.
  • CGViews, more genome comparison tools here.
  • How to organize those messy analysis files, flows, etc.. Read this.
